timeline.bodyText:
1.HBaseTestBase will pull up a HBase cluster which is a heavy action.
we can move this test to HBaseConnectorITCase avoid pulling up the cluster twice.
timeline.author: leonardBang

timeline.bodyText:
2.HBaseRowInputFormat is used by legacy connector, HBaseRowDataInputFormat is used by new connector,
we can cover them in HBaseConnectorITCase via parameterized parameter 'isLegacyConnector' easily

timeline.author: rmetzger
rmetzger

timeline.bodyText:
We will leak the connection if table.close() or resultScanner.close() fails with an exception.
I believe the proper way would be to wrap each close in a separate try block, and catch and log the error.
timeline.author: rmetzger

replies.bodyText: @rmetzger You are right, but resultScanner.close() doesn't throw exception. Therefore, I just add the close of the connection into catch block.
replies.author: SteNicholas

timeline.bodyText:
If you make this method throws IOException, you don't need to wrap the IOExceptions in HBaseRowDataInputFormat.connectToTable() into RuntimeExceptions.
Throwing an IOException is not a problem, because initTable is called in open(); which throws an IOException as well.
timeline.author: rmetzger

replies.bodyText: @rmetzger Good idea. I have followed up with your point to throws IOException for initTable().
replies.author: SteNicholas

timeline.author: wuchong

timeline.bodyText: The duplicate close looks strange to me. I think @rmetzger gave a nice idea above. You can just catch and log the error and move each close in a separate try block. You can take org.apache.flink.connector.hbase.sink.HBaseSinkFunction#close as an example. That will be much clean.
timeline.author: wuchong
